review.title: Semantic Similarity Strategies for Job Title Classification
review.abstract: Automatic and accurate classification of items enables numerous downstream applications in many domains. These applications can range from faceted browsing of items to product recommendations and big data analytics. In the online recruitment domain, we refer to classifying job ads to pre-defined or custom occupation categories as job title classification. A large-scale job title classification system can power various downstream applications such as semantic search, job recommendations and labor market analytics. In this paper, we discuss experiments conducted to improve our in-house job title classification system. The classification component of the system is composed of a two-stage coarse and fine level classifier cascade that classifies input text such as job title and/or job ads to one of the thousands of job titles in our taxonomy. To improve classification accuracy and effectiveness, we experiment with various semantic representation strategies such as average W2V vectors and document similarity measures such as Word Movers Distance (WMD). Our initial results show an overall improvement in accuracy of Carotene[1].

sections.text: Semantic Similarity Strategies for Job Title Classification Yun Zhu, Faizan Javed, Ozgur Ozturk Careerbuilder LLC.5550-A Peachtree Pkwy Norcross, GA 30092 {yun.zhu, faizan.javed, ozgur.ozturk} @ careerbuilder.com ABSTRACT Automatic and precise job classification allows numerous downstream job applications in many areas. These applications can range from multi-faceted surfing of articles to product recommendations to big data analytics. In the online recruitment domain, we refer to the classification of job ads by predefined or custom occupation categories as classification. A large-scale job title classification system can drive various downstream applications such as semantic search, job recommendations and job market analyses. In this essay we discuss experiments that have been conducted to improve our own job classification system.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Many e-commerce and web properties have the need to automatically classify millions of items into thousands of categories with a high degree of accuracy. Such large-scale item classification systems have many downstream applications such as product recommendations, multi-faceted search, semantic search, and big data analysis. In the online recruiting field, job classification can support applications such as labor market analysis, job recommendations, and semantic search. We refer to the classification of job ads (text documents consisting of titles, descriptions, and requirement fields) into predefined or custom occupational groups as classification. For the automatic classification of job titles, we have developed a system called Carotene that: i) has a taxonomy discovery component that builds clustering techniques from data sets to create a custom job title taxonomy, and ii) uses a two-tiered gross registry and fine-tiered SVM classification to create a custom job title taxonomy.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: 4.1 Test Use Case We evaluate performance by assigning KNN's job classification task, i.e. classifying the job title of the query according to the titles that appear most similar to our knowledge: "Entry-level Java Developer," "Matlab programmer New york," "J2EE engineer," if k = 3. Then the query title is classified as "Java Developer," because two of the three most similar titles ("Entry-level Java Developer" and "J2EE Engineer") are normalized and classified as "Java Developer." 4.2 Results Our test data contain 1667 human-labeled query titles and the knowledge base contains 1002737 reference titles that fall into 5425 predefined employment categories. referenceMentions.context: Our initial results show an overall improvement in accuracy of Carotene[1].
More details on the system can be found in [1].
In the enriching vectors approach [2], a document representation is enriched with some or all of the following: hypernyms, synonyms and related concepts.
Semantic kernels [3] leverage a semantic proximity matrix to transform document representations into linearly separable semantic representations.
In [4], enriching vectors and semantic kernels were used to classify medical text.
However, [5] details a semantic kernel approach that actually improved the performance of the SVM algorithm when the dimensionality of the input feature space is large and training data is scarce.
For computing similarities between documents, the WMD distance [6] has recently been shown to provide lower classification errors when used with distance-based classifiers.
For job title classification, LinkedIn uses a phrase-based classification system that relies on the near-sufficiency property of short text [7].
A semantic enrichment approach to job title classification is discussed in [8].
Word2vec (W2V), developed by Mikolov et al [9], uses shallow neural network to produce high dimensional vector representations for words and phrases.
Kusner et al [6] present speed improvements by filtering unlikely candidates using functions that has lower time complexity and are proved to be lower-bounds to WMD.
Quoc Le and Tomas Mikolov [10] applied sentiment analysis and information retrieval tests to paragraph vector similarity.
